item.title: Freedom-Promoting Jobs
item.description:
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="400" caption="Candlemaker on Flickr"][/caption]

This is a repost of an article I wrote for another blog on career advice for young people.

“You just have to do your own thing, no matter what anyone says. It's your life.” - Ethan Embry

There are plenty of reasons out there why you would want to avoid a job like the plague. After all, there is a reason Robert Kiyosaki, author of Rich Dad, Poor Dad, refers to the dreaded word as a mere acronym for Just Over Broke. Nevertheless, getting a job is the easiest way there is to make money, if not necessarily the most desirable, and as such is an invaluable method for providing the necessary foundation to jump off to freedom. Let’s be ridiculous and say we want a job with few hours, lots of freedom, and plenty of money. Where on earth do you find one like that? Before we go on, let me define what exactly I mean when I say Job.

item.title: Don't Be Afraid to Reach for Your Goals
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_746" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Source: ~dip on Flickr"][/caption]

People have a lot of preconceived notions about what they deserve: what they deserve to be called, what they deserve to have, what they deserve to be paid, who they deserve to love and be loved by. We set limits on our own potential, not because we want to hold ourselves back, but rather because we think it is the just way. The thought pattern might go like this: "I've only been writing regularly for a few weeks, so I don't deserve a published novel." Ironically, people often are afraid to reach for their goals, because they don't think they are worthy of them.

item.title: More Job Offers, and Professional Integrity
item.description: Too much of a good thing can be problematic. Such is the case with job offers. I was recently offered a position at Forbes, where I have been helping out on the social media team in exchange for experience. I very much appreciated the offer, and my first instinct was to immediately accept. But I had made other commitments that I didn't feel entirely comfortable walking away from on such short notice. So I declined the offer. I've gotten reactions ranging from disbelief, to surprise, to admiration, to declarations of my stupidity.
